articles.headline: Fewer Americans Strike Out for New Jobs, Crimping the Recovery
articles.snippet: Economists have become increasingly worried that a slide in job turnover and relocation rates is undermining the economy’s dynamism.
articles.abstract: Economists have become increasingly worried that a slide in job turnover and relocation rates is undermining the economy’s dynamism.
articles.lead_paragraph: By covered wagon and jetliner, from East Coast to West, Rust Belt to Sun Belt, Americans’ propensity to be on the move – to new jobs and new places – has historically provided the economy with a critical dose of oomph.

articles.headline: Reeling From 2016 Chaos, G.O.P. Mulls Overhaul of Primaries
articles.snippet: Iowa and New Hampshire could lose their coveted status as gatekeepers to the presidency, and independents could be barred from voting in Republican contests.
articles.abstract: Iowa and New Hampshire could lose their coveted status as gatekeepers to the presidency, and independents could be barred from voting in Republican contests.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Leaders of the Republican Party have begun internal deliberations over what would be fundamental changes to the way its presidential nominees are chosen, a recognition that the chaotic process that played out this year is seriously flawed and helped exacerbate tensions within the party.

articles.headline: Automakers Befriend Start-Ups Like Uber, Girding Against a Changing Car Culture
articles.snippet: Companies like Toyota and Volkswagen are supporting the tech companies working to change the way people travel by car.
articles.abstract: Companies like Toyota and Volkswagen are supporting the tech companies working to change the way people travel by car.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Automakers are looking toward a technology-driven future, one where they increasingly acknowledge that getting around may not require owning a car.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: New Crop of Companies Reaping Profits From Wasted Food
articles.snippet: With as much as 40 percent of the American food supply going into the trash, food waste has become a platform for commerce.
articles.abstract: With as much as 40 percent of the American food supply going into the trash, food waste has become a platform for commerce.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just as Rumpelstiltskin spun gold from straw, scores of new companies are trying to spin profits out of food waste.

articles.headline: Shaken, Taliban Begin Effort to Replace Dead Leader, Mullah Mansour
articles.snippet: The effort to replace the leader killed in an American drone strike comes amid concerns over safety, intensifying divisions and access to money.
articles.abstract: The effort to replace the leader killed in an American drone strike comes amid concerns over safety, intensifying divisions and access to money.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the second time in less than a year, senior Taliban leaders have convened in the Pakistani city of Quetta to deliberate how to replace a dead supreme leader.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Taimoor Shah

articles.headline: Paramount Plays Leading Role in Battle Over Viacom
articles.snippet: The film and TV studio’s fate could affect the future of Sumner Redstone’s $40 billion entertainment empire.
articles.abstract: The film and TV studio’s fate could affect the future of Sumner Redstone’s $40 billion entertainment empire.
articles.lead_paragraph: About 22 years ago, the media mogul Sumner M. Redstone beat out Barry Diller in a fierce bidding war for Paramount Pictures, striking a deal worth nearly $10 billion for the film and television studio. Mr. Redstone famously celebrated the prize with the toast: “Here’s to us who won.”

articles.headline: ELeague Adapts TV to the Gaming Sensibility
articles.snippet: If all goes as planned, ELeague on TBS will be TV created in the image of successful online e-sports, rather than the other way around
articles.abstract: If all goes as planned, ELeague on TBS will be TV created in the image of successful online e-sports, rather than the other way around
articles.lead_paragraph: The world of competitive video game sports has moved to the mainstream without much help from television. More than ever, though, television wants to get into the action.
articles.byline: By John Herrman and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Taliban Name Lesser-Known Cleric as Their New Leader
articles.snippet: The insurgency confirmed its former leader’s death in a drone strike, and it said the new one, Mawlawi Haibatullah Akhundzada, would continue the war.
articles.abstract: The insurgency confirmed its former leader’s death in a drone strike, and it said the new one, Mawlawi Haibatullah Akhundzada, would continue the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Faced with a choice between two obvious candidates to take over the Taliban — one the young son of the insurgency’s founder, the other chief of the Haqqani terrorist network — a small slice of the group’s leadership instead chose “none of the above” on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal, Taimoor Shah and Zahra Nader

articles.headline: Corporate America Chases the Mythical Millennial
articles.snippet: The expensive quest to discover what millennials want misses two things: Each is an individual, and collectively they are much like other generations.
articles.abstract: The expensive quest to discover what millennials want misses two things: Each is an individual, and collectively they are much like other generations.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re reading this article voluntarily, you’re probably not a millennial, because everyone knows millennials don’t read news. In fact, there’s a pretty good chance you look down on millennials. Perhaps you consider them entitled, indulgent, needy and a little too much to bear — or maybe you’re simply skeeved by their weird headgear, strange hieroglyphs and intricate courtship rituals.

articles.headline: Feeling Let Down and Left Behind, With Little Hope for Better
articles.snippet: In a moment riddled with economic and social worries, an e-cigarette shop in Wilkes County, N.C., is an oasis for some young Appalachians.
articles.abstract: In a moment riddled with economic and social worries, an e-cigarette shop in Wilkes County, N.C., is an oasis for some young Appalachians.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH WILKESBORO, N.C. — Kody Foster had finished his Wednesday afternoon shift at the warehouse where he earns $12.50 per hour. Normally, he would be packing himself into his Ford Focus, with its Bernie Sanders sticker and plaque with the number 48, in honor of the stock-car racer Jimmie Johnson.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Is Criticized for Private Emails in State Dept. Review
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton and her aides have played down the inquiries, saying that she would cooperate with investigators to put the email issue behind her.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton and her aides have played down the inquiries, saying that she would cooperate with investigators to put the email issue behind her.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department’s inspector general on Wednesday sharply criticized Hillary Clinton’s exclusive use of a private email server while she was secretary of state, saying that she had not sought permission to use it and would not have received it if she had.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: In Obama’s Visit to Hiroshima, a Complex Calculus of Asian Politics
articles.snippet: The president’s visit to Vietnam and particularly Japan highlights old grievances as well as the current power struggles among nations big and small in Asia.
articles.abstract: The president’s visit to Vietnam and particularly Japan highlights old grievances as well as the current power struggles among nations big and small in Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISE, Japan — Eleven United States presidents have served since President Harry S. Truman decided to drop an atomic weapon on Hiroshima, and none has set foot in that traumatized city in the 71 years since, at least not while in office.

articles.headline: A Traveler’s Guide to Taking a Smartphone Abroad
articles.snippet: There are two ways to take your phone overseas and get data — the frugal way, which requires a bit of tinkering, and the pay-full-price way.
articles.abstract: There are two ways to take your phone overseas and get data — the frugal way, which requires a bit of tinkering, and the pay-full-price way.
articles.lead_paragraph: The summer travel season will soon be upon us, with notions of escape, unplugging and faraway lands.
